Any restrictions must be narrowly tailored, evidence-based, and applied with robust procedural safeguards to prevent abuse. Outside narrowly defined harms, counter-speech, civic education, and community-based remediation are preferable to censorship. This combined legal and social strategy preserves democratic debate while protecting vulnerable people.

A principled middle ground preserves broad freedom of expression while imposing narrowly tailored limits only when speech directly causes or imminently risks violence, credible threats, or systematic harassment. Clear definitions, due process, and transparent enforcement keep limits from becoming tools of censorship, and nonlegal responses—education, restorative practices, and vigorous counterspeech—address offensive but noncriminal views. Together these measures protect both civic liberty and human dignity.
